author: killari.
content: What happens if a block proposer proposes block late based on some validators but in time based on some other validators?

author: potuz
content: what's the scope of this question? proposer boost in Fork choice or just in general?

author: killari.
content: just in general. I wonder how the chain handles that discrepancy

author: potuz
content: well you see this quite often now: some blocks get few votes, this is typically the situation that the block arrived late to most validators, but some managed to see them on time. One typical scenario is a block proposed late by a pool running many keys. In this case the pool submits the block and the attestations for this block, but no one else gets the block in time and they send attestations for the previous head. Depending on when the next block proposer gets this block it may be orphaned or not

author: killari.
content: oh, so the next proposer can't sensor the other block in that case?

author: killari.
content: could they just sensor it even if they saw it, but they are malicious?

author: potuz
content: It's risky, this is the issue of having aggregation at 8 seconds while attestations at 4 and proposals for the next block at 12. Blocks that arrive at 5 seconds are a problem, no one can attest for them, but the next proposer (and the whole network) do see the valid block. So if the next proposer decides to censor the late block, he's taking a risk that his own block will be orphaned. Every single stock client in this situation will have the next proposer not censor the late block

author: potuz
content: proposer boost changes this situation a little bit, giving a late block a penalty in fork choice.

author: killari.
content: hmm, how does the proposer boost works? is there some info about it?

author: potuz
content: check this and the links in the description https://github.com/ethereum/consensus-specs/pull/2730
